docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Facing NATO Deadline, Troops Leave Kosovo Yugoslavia began what appeared to be serious troop withdrawals from many positions in Kosovo, only a day before a NATO deadline and under threat of air strikes. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: In his quest for another term, Gov. George E. Pataki and his fellow Republicans have mounted the most successful fund-raising operation in New York history, drawing support from thousands of donors, many of whom share a common trait: they do business with the state. Mr. Pataki and the Republican State Committee have collected more than $33 million since 1995, helping him ward off some formidable challengers and allowing him to spend well over $1 million a week in the final stretch of the campaign.

headline.main: Many Donors To Pataki Do State Business

docs.abstract: New York Gov George E Pataki and his fellow Republicans, in quest for second term, have mounted most successful fund-raising operation in state's history, drawing support from thousands of donors who share common trait of doing business with state; have collected $33 million since 1995, helping Pataki ward off some formidable challengers and allowing him to spend well over $1 million per week in final stretch of campaign; millions came from donors with specific interests, consultants and businesses given construction projects worth as much as tens of millions of dollars each; in many cases, donations were solicited around same time contributors had matters before administration; while some donors have done business with state for years and have contributed to whoever is in power, Pataki has attracted more money from wider spectrum of busineses--many of whom began giving large amounts only when state was making decisions important to their bottom lines; photo; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Department of Labor sued Time Warner Inc. and officials of nine corporate pension and health plans today, saying they wrongly denied health and retirement coverage to hundreds of employees. The workers were mistakenly classified as independent contractors or temporary workers rather than official employees entitled to the benefits, the suit says, adding that the company violated the Employee Retirement Income Security Act.

headline.main: Time Warner Is Sued by U.S. In Employee Benefits Case

docs.abstract: US Labor Department sues Time Warner Inc and officials of nine corporate pension and health plans, saying they wrongly denied health and retirement coverage to hundreds of employees; suit says workers were mistakenly classified as independent contractors or temporary workers rather than official employees entitled to benefits, adding that company violated Employee Retirement Income Security Act (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The first commandment for couples wanting to adopt babies is: Put yourselves across. And they do, in spunky performances on videotapes, in lush scrapbooks and in professional portraiture smiling on the Internet. Many speak on the Web pages that crowd electronic registries of ''waiting families.'' Gloyd and Penny, for example, say, ''We pray daily for our birth mother and baby -- whoever and wherever they are.'' David and Paula promise, ''This child will be overwhelmed by love and affection.'' Rex and Carol wait, after 14 years of marriage, with a spaniel named Brittney and a vacation home four miles from Disney World.

headline.main: Market Puts Price Tags on the Priceless

docs.abstract: Second of three articles in series In Search of a Child: The Baby Bazaar; focuses on competition among infertile couples for smaller and smaller supply of white American-born infants; experts say imbalance between demand and supply allows money to play defining role, with couples spending average of $15,000 to $20,000 and some paying up to $100,000 to adopt newborn; sales of babies are illegal, but thousands of intermediaries sell access to young women who might relinquish babies, leaving only thinnest line between buying child and buying adoption services that lead to baby; table of payments permitted in various states; photos (L)
docs.snippet: The first commandment for couples wanting to adopt babies is: Put yourselves across. And they do, in spunky performances on videotapes, in lush scrapbooks and in professional portraiture smiling on the Internet.    Many speak on the Web pages that...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was not the five inches of gray muck that covered their once-green lawn or even their water-sopped mobile home -- its floors gone, its furniture ruined -- that disheartened Bob Dagnall and Dawn Kawzinsky. One month after Hurricane Georges pushed six feet of water across the sea-level Sands subdivision, leaving the couple an uninhabitable shell with a $39,000 mortgage, they learned that rebuilding here will require a special home on 12-foot pillars on a downsized lot.

headline.main: In Devastated Keys, a Call to Improve

docs.abstract: Hurricane Georges reveals uncontrolled and unsafe development in Florida Keys; many people whose mobile homes were damaged cannot afford to comply with higher Federal standards they must meet to get building permits; some residents are hurriedly patching up homes and apartments to avoid tougher rules; political pressure is building to relax codes for people already hit hard; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Karen Ann Koza, a daughter of Arlene F. Koza of Manhattan and the late John J. Koza, was married yesterday to Kevin John Falowski, a son of Mary and Ronald Falowski of Flushing, Queens. The Rev. John T. Mulligan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in Manhattan. The couple graduated from Manhattan College.

docs.lead_paragraph: MARTY WHITMAN undoubtedly the only person who ever called him Martin was his mother -- is on a crusade. The man who has made several fortunes betting on corporate lost causes has now taken on Japan, the epicenter of the Asian financial crisis. At a time when many foreign investors have bailed out, Mr. Whitman's Third Avenue Value fund has 11.4 percent of its net assets sunk into Japanese stocks, mostly nonlife insurance companies and Toyota Motor Corporation affiliates.

headline.main: Preacher to the Doubters in Japan

docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with Marty Whitman, 74, whose Third Avenue Value fund, bucking trend, has invested heavily in Japanese stocks; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DANA REEVE said the reality of her Broadway debut last Thursday first hit home a few weeks ago when workers at the Eugene O'Neill Theater were installing the marquee for ''More to Love: A Big Fat Comedy.'' The three-person play was written by and starred Rob Bartlett, a comedian who often does impersonations on ''Imus in the Morning,'' the syndicated radio show.

headline.main: Dana Reeve Makes Debut on Broadway

docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with Dana Reeve, wife of actor Christopher Reeve; she comments on her Broadway debut, starring opposite playwright and comedian Rob Bartlett, in More to Love: A Big Fat Comedy, at Eugene O'Neill Theater; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER examining the patient's tongue and taking his pulse at various points, Darlene Easton inserted several needles into the area surrounding his knee, while Joel Lafemina recorded his observations on a chart. ''Have you been having any allergy problems this week?'' Ms. Easton asked the patient, Paul Masiulis of East Meadow. ''Your pulse feels a little weak.''

headline.main: College Gets Go-Ahead for Holistic Degrees

docs.lead_paragraph: SHOULD Medicare be expanded to cover prescription drugs? Should premiums be set on a sliding scale based on income? Should the eligibility age be kept at 65 or raised to 67 or lowered to 63? Should beneficiaries be enrolled in managed care? Should taxes be increased to pay for the increased cost of Medicare? Should payments to medical providers be further reduced? The League of Women Voters wants to hear from the public about their reactions to those and other possible changes to Medicare, the health-insurance program that serves 34 million people 65 years and older and 5 million disabled people.
docs.abstract: League of Women Voters schedules public meeting in New Rochelle, NY, to discuss possible changes in Medicare benefits, costs and eligiblity (M)
